case_name: Additional Settlement Commissioner and the State of Bombay v. Yeshwant Madhao Mahajan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 281 of 1959 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 281 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1955, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petition No. 288 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1955, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petition No. 288 of 1954.

facts.text: Dhanora is an Izara village in Taluka Pusad in the State of Madhya Pradesh with total area of 2,375 acres 3 gunthas.

anchor.surface_text: Out of a total area of 2,375 acres 3 gunthas of Dhanora-an Izara village in Taluka Pusad in the State of Madhya Pradesh-2,283 acres and 28 gunthas is assessed land

facts.text: Of Dhanora village, 2,283 acres and 28 gunthas is assessed land and 91 acres and 15 gunthas is unassessed.

anchor.surface_text: -2,283 acres and 28 gunthas is assessed land and the remaining 91 acres and 15 gunthas is unassessed.

facts.text: Surat Singh was the proprietor of the village Dhanora.

anchor.surface_text: One Surat Singh who was the proprietor of the village, by sale deed dated May 24, 1947, companyveyed

facts.text: Surat Singh conveyed an undivided half share in Dhanora village to Yeshwant Madhao Mahajan by sale deed dated May 24, 1947, for Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: by sale deed dated May 24, 1947, companyveyed an undivided half share in the village to Yeshwant Madhao Mahajan-hereinafter called Mahajan-for Rs. 25,000/-

facts.text: On May 24, 1947, Surat Singh executed a kabulayat lease deed for five years in respect of the same half share land to Mahajan for cultivation at annual rental of Rs. 3,000.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day executed a kabulayat  lease deed  for five years in respect of the same land for cultivation at an annual rental of Rs. 3,000/-

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1 of 1951 was enacted and brought into operation on March 14, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature of the Madhya Pradesh State enacted the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1 of 1951-hereinafter called the Act- to provide for acquisition ... The Act was brought into operation on March 14, 1951.

facts.text: Village Dhanora vested in the State Government by operation of section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of the village Dhanora which had vested by the operation of s. 3 of the Act in the State Government.

facts.text: Compensation Officer, Yeotmal started an enquiry about assessment of compensation in respect of Dhanora village.

anchor.surface_text: The Compensation Officer, Yeotmal started an enquiry about assessment of companypensation in respect of the village Dhanora which had vested by the operation of s. 3 of the Act in the State Government.

facts.text: Mahajan claimed before Compensation Officer to retain possession of half share in all fallow lands in village leased under deed dated May 24, 1947, as home farm.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Compensation officer, Mahajan claimed to retain possession of a half share in all the fallow lands in the village which had been leased by him under the deed  kabulayat  dated May, 24, 1947, to Surat Singh on the plea that these lands were home farm.

facts.text: Compensation Officer rejected Mahajan's claim that fallow lands were home farm.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was rejected by the Compensation Officer and the order of the Compensation Officer was companyfirmed in appeal

facts.text: Order of Compensation Officer confirmed in appeal by Additional Settlement Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: by the Additional Settlement Commissioner. Mahajan then applied to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Mahajan filed petition under Art. 226 in Nagpur High Court seeking quashing of orders, declaration of Schedule A lands as home-farm, and mandamus for possession.

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan then applied to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a direction quashing the order of the Additional Settlement Commissioner and the Compensation Officer and for a declaration that the lands mentioned in Schedule A attached to the petition be declared home-farm and for a writ of mandamus against the State of Madhya Pradesh to deliver possession of all the lands mentioned in that Schedule.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court quashed the order of Additional Settlement Commissioner insofar as it related to undivided half share in Survey Nos. 1 to 91 except those in possession of specified tenants and already recognized home-farm, and directed Compensation Officer to decide claim per judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court quashed the order of the Additional Settlement Commissioner in so far as it related to the undivided half share in Survey Nos. 1 to 91 except those in possession of the specified tenants and also those already recognised as home- farm and directed the Compensation Officer to decide the claim made by Mahajan in the light of the law laid down in the judgment.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court with special leave by Additional Settlement Commissioner and State of Bombay (substituted for Madhya Pradesh via States Reorganization Act, 1956).

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court, the Additional Settlement Commissioner and the State of Bombay, which had by virtue of the States Reorganization Act, 1956, been substituted for the State of Madhya Pradesh, have appealed to this Court with special leave.

facts.text: Dispute relates to half share in lands in village which remained fallow on date of notification under s.3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute in this appeal relates to a half share in those lands in the village which had remained fallow on the date of the numberification under s. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: By sale deed dated May 24, 1947, Mahajan became proprietor of undivided half share in entire village.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the sale deed dated May 24, 1947, Mahajan was the proprietor of the undivided half share in the entire village

facts.text: Under kabulayat, Mahajan granted lease for cultivation of undivided half share to Surat Singh.

anchor.surface_text: and under the kabulayat he had granted to Surat Singh a lease for cultivation of the undivided half share purchased by him.

facts.text: Lands specified in Schedule A to the petition were lying fallow on the crucial date.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly the lands specified in Schedule A to the petition were on the crucial date lying fallow.

facts.text: Mahajan was superior holder of half share in fallow lands held by Surat Singh as lessee.

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan was undoubtedly at the date of vesting the superior holder of the half share in the fallow lands which were held by Surat Singh as lessee from him.

facts.text: Lands in Schedule A are assessed lands.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule A to the petition sets out the description of the various lands which Mahajan claimed should be treated as home-farm land. Each of these lands is assessed.

facts.text: Certain lands in the village were lying fallow wholly or partially at the date of vesting.

anchor.surface_text: Certain lands in the village, it is true, were lying fallow wholly or partially at the date of the vesting,

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the High Court was right in holding that lands held by lessee from superior holder qualify as home-farm even if lying fallow.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the words of cl.  ii  of s. 2 g   3  were explicit and a survey number which was lying fallow but was held by a lessee from the superior holder fell within the definition of home-farm.
Mahajan then applied to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a direction quashing the order
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1955, of the former Nagpur High Court

The Legislature of the Madhya Pradesh State enacted the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1 of 1951-hereinafter called the Act- to provide for acquisition ... The Act was brought into operation on March 14, 1951.

concepts.unlisted_label: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1 of 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Act for acquisition of proprietary rights in estates, etc., and provision for compensation

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act provides, in so far as it is material, that on and from a date to be specified by a notification by the State Government in this behalf, all proprietary rights in an estate, mahal, alienated village or alienated land, as the case may be, in the area specified in the notification, vesting in a proprietor of such estate, mahal, alienated village, alienated land, or in a person having interest in such proprietary right through the proprietor, shall pass from such proprietor or such other person to and vest in the State for the purposes of the State free of all encumbrances.

concepts.interpretation: Vesting of proprietary rights in the State on notified date free of encumbrances.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: and the State of Bombay, which had by virtue of the States Reorganization Act, 1956, been substituted for the State of Madhya Pradesh, have appealed

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3, MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Vesting of proprietary rights in State Government

anchor.surface_text: those lands can be regarded home-far if they be so regarded, by virtue of s. 4 (2) of the Act Mahajan will be entitled to retain possession of those lands.

concepts.interpretation: Proprietor continues to retain possession of home-farm land notwithstanding vesting under sub-s.(1).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: other than occupied lands and home-stead lands, and of all interests vesting in the State under s. 3 on the date of the vesting, and, by s. 8, duty is

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4(2), MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Exception allowing retention of home-farm land

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 (1) sets out the consequence of the vesting. By cl. (a) of s. 4 (1), all rights, title and interest vesting in the proprietor or any person having interest in such proprietary right through the proprietor in such area including land (cultivable or barren), cease and are vested in the State for the purposes of the State free from all encumbrances.

concepts.interpretation: Cessation of proprietary rights including in cultivable or barren land upon vesting.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s. 3 of the Act. By virtue of the sale deed dated May 24, 1947, Mahajan was the proprietor of the undivided half share in the entire village and unde

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4(1), MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Consequences of vesting of proprietary rights

anchor.surface_text: But sub-s. (2) provides that Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), the proprietor shall continue to retain the possession of his home-stead, home- farm land . Home-farm land is defined, in so far as it is material, in s. 2 (g) as ... 3 in relation to Berar, all land included in holdings which is- ... (ii) held by a lessee from the superior holder...

concepts.interpretation: Includes land lying fallow held by lessee from superior holder; explicit words cover fallow lands leased for cultivation.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ase for cultivation of the undivided half share purchased by him. Undoubtedly the lands specified in Schedule A to the petition were on the crucial da

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(g), MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1951 (home-farm land definition)
concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of home-farm land including land under personal cultivation, fallow per practice, or held by lessee/tenant from superior holder

anchor.surface_text: The expression holding is not defined in the Act, but by cl. (d) of s. 2 expressions not defined in the Act in relation to Berar but used or explained in the Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928, have the meaning assigned to those expressions in the latter Act.

concepts.interpretation: Undefined terms in Act relating to Berar take meaning from Berar Land Revenue Code.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: cl.  d  of s. 2 expressions number defined in the Act in relation to Berar but used or explained in

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2(d), MP Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1951
concepts.unlisted_description: Interpretation clause for terms from Berar Land Revenue Code

anchor.surface_text: The Berar Land Revenue Code defines holding as (a) a parcel of land separately assessed to land revenue and (b) in reference to land held by a tenant-a parcel of land held from a landlord under one lease or set of conditions.

concepts.interpretation: Includes survey numbers separately assessed; applies to undivided shares in holdings.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928, have the meaning assigned to those expressions in the latter Act. The Berar Land Revenue Code defines holding as  a

concepts.unlisted_description: Deputy Commissioner takes charge of vested lands except occupied/home-stead

anchor.surface_text: and, by s. 8, duty is imposed on the State Government to pay every proprietor, who is divested of proprietary rights, compensation in accordance with the rules contained in Schedule I.

issues.text: The question which falls to be determined is whether those lands can be regarded home-farm

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls to be determined is whether those lands can be regarded home-far if they be so regarded, by virtue of s. 4 2  of the Act Mahajan will be entitled to retain possession of those lands.

issues.text: in respect of an undivided interest in land, the superior holder is not entitled to the benefit of s. 4 2 , because it is not a holding

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie the claim of Mahajan was covered by cl. g 3 ii of s. 2 of the Act, and Mahajan was entitled to the benefit of the exception in s. 4 2 . But counsel for the State contends that in respect of an undivided interest in land, the superior holder is not entitled to the benefit of s. 4 2 , because it is not a holding.

issues.text: the land which is, at the date of vesting, lying fallow otherwise than in accordance with the usual agricultural practice can never be regarded as home-farm

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, he contends that the land which is, at the date of vesting, lying fallow otherwise than in accordance with the usual agricultural practice can never be regarded as home-farm. In our view, there is no substance in either of these contentions.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule A to the petition sets out the description of the various lands which Mahajan claimed should be treated as home-farm land. Each of these lands is assessed. The expression holding is not defined in the Act, but by cl. (d) of s. 2 ... In other words a part of the holding or an undivided interest in the holding may also be home-farm land if it otherwise fulfils the requirements of cl. (i) (ii) or (iii) of sub-cl. (3).

arguments.claim: Lands leased for cultivation qualify as home-farm under s.4(2) even if lying fallow at vesting; no exclusion for fallow lands in cl.(ii); lease evidences intent to cultivate

anchor.surface_text: Certain lands in the village, it is true, were lying fallow wholly or partially at the date of the vesting, but the lands having been granted in lease for cultivation, in our judgment, they are by virtue of s. 4 2 to be retained in the possession of the proprietor ... default on the part of the lessee to cultivate those lands will not, deprive the lessor-proprietor of the benefit granted to him by the statute.

arguments.claim: High Court correctly held that cl.(ii) of s.2(g)(3) explicitly covers survey number lying fallow held by lessee from superior holder as home-farm

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the words of cl. ii of s. 2 g 3 were explicit and a survey number which was lying fallow but was held by a lessee from the superior holder fell within the definition of home-farm.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the words of cl. (ii) of s. 2(g)(3) were explicit and a survey number which was lying fallow but was held by a lessee from the superior holder fell within the definition of home-farm.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that the words of cl. ii of s. 2 g 3 were explicit and a survey number which was lying fallow but was held by a lessee from the superior holder fell within the definition of home-farm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual interpretation of s.2(g)(3)(ii); affirms High Court; no exclusion for fallow lands in clause (ii); lease for cultivation suffices.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention that in respect of an undivided interest in land, the superior holder is not entitled to the benefit of s. 4(2), because it is not a holding.

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan was undoubtedly at the date of vesting the superior holder of the half share in the fallow lands which were held by Surat Singh as lessee from him. Prima facie the claim of Mahajan was covered by cl. g 3 ii of s. 2 of the Act, and Mahajan was entitled to the benefit of the exception in s. 4 2 . But counsel for the State contends that in respect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Holding defined via Berar Land Revenue Code includes assessed parcels; all land in holdings covers parts/undivided shares if conditions met.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention that land lying fallow at the date of vesting otherwise than in accordance with usual agricultural practice can never be regarded as home-farm.

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, he contends that the land which is, at the date of vesting, lying fallow otherwise than in accordance with the usual agricultural practice can never be regarded as home-farm. In our view, there is no substance in either of these contentions. Schedule A to the petition sets out the description of the various lands which Mahajan claimed should be treated as home-farm land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause (ii) lacks limitation of cl.(i); lease evidences intent to cultivate; lessee default does not deprive superior holder.

holdings.text: A part of the holding or an undivided interest in the holding may also be home-farm land if it otherwise fulfils the requirements of cl. (i), (ii) or (iii) of sub-cl. (3) of s.2(g).

anchor.surface_text: Schedule A to the petition sets out the description of the various lands which Mahajan claimed should be treated as home-farm land. Each of these lands is assessed. The expression holding is not defined in the Act, but by cl. (d) of s. 2 expressions not defined in the Act in relation to Berar but used or explained in the Berar Land Revenue Code, 1928, have the meaning assigned to those expressions in the latter Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Berar Code defines holding as assessed parcel or land under one lease; survey nos. are holdings; definition covers all land included therein.

holdings.text: Lands having been granted in lease for cultivation are by virtue of s. 4(2) to be retained in the possession of the proprietor notwithstanding provision of cl. (i) of s. 4; default by lessee does not deprive lessor-proprietor of statutory benefit.

anchor.surface_text: That a half share in the village-which is included in the Schedule to the petition-was granted to Surat Singh on lease for cultivation cannot be gainsaid in view of the express terms of the kabulayat. Certain lands in the village, it is true, were lying fallow wholly or partially at the date of the vesting, but the lands having been granted in lease for cultivation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express/implied exclusion of fallow lands from s.4(2); lease intent overrides actual cultivation status at vesting.
